title: How to Roast Green Chiles

steps.headline: Decide what variety to roast.
steps.description:
Because green peppers vary in size and heat, choose your favorite green peppers to roast. Keep in mind that thin, narrow green chiles will roast faster than larger ones. Try roasting:
Anaheim peppers
California peppers
Hatch peppers
Jalapeno peppers
Poblano peppers
Pasilla peppers

steps.headline: Buy or pick the green chiles.
steps.description: If you're purchasing the peppers, look for green peppers that have firm flesh and a bright green color. Avoid chiles that have discolored spots or soft areas on the flesh. If you're picking your green chiles, plan on roasting them within 1 to 2 days or they may begin to soften. Look for straight chiles since these roast more evenly than curly ones.

steps.headline: Rinse and dry the green chiles.
steps.description: Run cold water over as many green chiles as you plan to roast. Lay the chiles on a kitchen towel and pat them dry.

steps.headline: Consider wearing gloves when you handle them.
steps.description: If you have sensitive skin and are handling spicy chiles, you may want to wear protective gloves. Wear kitchen gloves or food-safe latex gloves any time you touch the chiles.

steps.headline: Turn a gas burner to high and place the chiles on the burner.
steps.description: If you're roasting large green peppers such as bell peppers, place 1 or 2 directly on the burner. To roast smaller chiles, lay a heat-proof wire-mesh on the burner. Place the small green chiles on the wire-mesh.

steps.headline: Heat the chiles for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Let the chiles come into direct contact with the flame of the burner for 5 minutes. The chiles should blister and pop as they char.

steps.headline: Flip and roast the chiles for 5 more minutes.
steps.description: Use tongs to carefully flip over each pepper. Roast the other side of the chiles until they're blackened.

steps.headline: Transfer the chiles to a bowl and steam them for 10 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and use the tongs to transfer the roasted chiles to a heat-proof bowl. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or a thick kitchen towel to trap the steam. Let the chiles steam for 10 to 15 minutes so the peels loosen.

steps.headline: Scrape the peel from the chiles.
steps.description: Set the steamed chiles on a cutting board and hold 1 by the stem. Use a small knife to scrape the peel off. It should flake off easily. Repeat this for every chile you roasted and discard the peels.

steps.headline: Seed and cut the chiles, if desired.
steps.description: Cut off the stem from each pepper and rinse the insides to remove the seeds. You can leave the chiles whole or cut them as small as you like.

steps.headline: Use or store the chiles.
steps.description: Make your favorite recipes with the green chiles. For example, stir chopped green chiles into scrambled eggs, soup, or salsas. To store the chiles in the refrigerator, bring them to room temperature and put them in an airtight container. Refrigerate them for up to 3 days or freeze them for 10 to 12 months.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 425 °F (218 °C) and arrange the chiles on a sheet.
steps.description: Get out a rimmed baking sheet and lay as many green chiles as you want to roast on the sheet. Ensure that they're in a single layer so they roast evenly.

steps.headline: Drizzle the chiles with oil.
steps.description: Evenly pour a few spoonfuls of canola or vegetable oil over the chiles.

steps.headline: Roast the chiles for 15 minutes.
steps.description: Cook them until they've softened and blistered on the top.

steps.headline: Flip the chiles and roast them for 10 more minutes.
steps.description: Remove the baking sheet from the oven and use tongs to turn over each chile. Return the sheet to the oven and roast the chiles for another 10 minutes so the other side blackens.

steps.headline: Cover and steam the chiles for 10 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: Turn off the oven and remove the roasted chiles from the oven. Use the tongs to transfer the chiles to a heat-proof bowl or bag. Cover the bowl tightly with plastic wrap or seal the bag shut. Leave the chiles to steam so their skins loosen.

steps.headline: Rub the skins off using your fingers and trim the chiles.
steps.description: Once the chiles are cool enough to handle, rub them between your fingers so the skins fall off. Use a small knife to cut off the stems and trim away the seeds. If you want to cut the chiles, chop them as finely as you want.

steps.headline: Use or store the roasted green chiles.
steps.description: Stuff the roasted chiles with rice or eggs. You can also stir the diced green chiles into dips, soups, and casseroles. If you want to store the chiles to use later, put them in an airtight container. Refrigerate them for up to 3 days or freeze them for 10 to 12 months.

steps.headline: Preheat the broiler to high.
steps.description: Adjust the top rack so it's 4 inches (10 cm) to 6 inches (15 cm) below the broiler element. If you can select the temperature of your broiler, set it between 400 °F (204 °C) and 450 °F (232 °C).

steps.headline: Arrange the green chiles on a baking sheet.
steps.description: Get out a rimmed baking sheet and lay a sheet of aluminum foil on it. Place your green chiles on the foil in a single layer. This will help them roast evenly.

steps.headline: Broil the chiles for 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Place the sheet under the broiler so 1 side of the chiles becomes charred and blistered. Avoid broiling the chiles until they turn completely black.

steps.headline: Flip the chiles over.
steps.description: Wear oven mitts and pull the sheet from under the broiler. Use tongs to flip each green chile over so the blackened side is on the bottom.

steps.headline: Broil the chiles for 3 to 5 more minutes.
steps.description: Place the sheet with the chiles back under the broiler and heat the chiles until they're charred and blistered on the top. Pull them out before they become totally black.

steps.headline: Steam the chiles for 10 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: Transfer the roasted chiles to a paper bag, food-safe plastic bag, or a heat-proof bowl. Close or seal the bag. If you're using a bowl, cover it tightly with plastic wrap. Leave the chiles to steam for 10 to 15 minutes. Steaming the chiles will cool them a little, which will make them easier to handle. The steam will also make it easier to rub off the peels.

steps.headline: Peel and seed the chiles.
steps.description: Remove the chiles from the bag or bowl and rub the peels a little to loosen them. Pull the peel off or use a knife to scrape it off. To remove the seeds, scrape against the insides of the chiles with a spoon. If you want to chop the chiles, cut them as finely as you like.

steps.headline: Use or store the chiles.
steps.description: You can use the green chiles in your favorite meals. Stir them into frittatas, stews, or braises. If you want to store the chiles, cool them to room temperature and refrigerate them in an airtight container for up to 3 days. You can also freeze the peppers for 10 to 12 months.

steps.headline: Finished.

Turn off the oven and remove the roasted chiles from the oven. Use the tongs to transfer the chiles to a heat-proof bowl or bag. Cover the bowl tightly with plastic wrap or seal the bag shut. Arrange the green chiles on a baking sheet. Get out a rimmed baking sheet and lay a sheet of aluminum foil on it. Place your green chiles on the foil in a single layer. Use tongs to flip each green chile over so the blackened side is on the bottom. Broil the chiles for 3 to 5 more minutes. If you're using a bowl, cover it tightly with plastic wrap. Leave the chiles to steam for 10 to 15 minutes. Steaming the chiles will cool them a little, which will make them easier to handle. The steam will also make it easier to rub off the peels. Peel and seed the chiles. Remove the chiles from the bag or bowl and rub the peels a little to loosen them.
